Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Nitrogen Cycle Responses to Increasing Presence of Parasitic Mistletoes in Australian Eucalypt Forests
Award.AbstractNarration:
Australian eucalypt forests are increasingly inundated with mistletoes, in large response to changes in land management. Mistletoes are parasitic plants that reduce the growth of their host eucalyptus trees but also promote increased bird diversity in forests, resulting in conflicting opinions about how mistletoes affect forest function and productivity. Assessing how biologically-important nutrients, such as nitrogen, cycle through forests in response to mistletoe parasitism may give insight into forest health and function. Changes in nitrogen processes resulting from increasing abundance of mistletoe will likely have ramifications for forest health and global climate, and may inform future land management decisions in Australian woodlands and elsewhere. This project, conducted in collaboration with Dr. Elise Pendall at the Hawkesbury Institute for the Environment at Western Sydney University in Australia, will explore the role of mistletoe for nitrogen cycling in eucalyptus woodlands. Dr. Pendall is a renowned ecosystem ecologist known for her work in biogeochemical cycling in response to ecological disturbances.

Relatively little is known about the impacts of Amyema miquelii mistletoe litter on decomposition, nitrification, and denitrification processes in woodlands dominated by Eucalyptus moluccana and E. fibrosa found in Cumberland Plain, Australia. Presumably, nitrogen-rich mistletoe litter could increase decomposition rates and serve as a substrate for increased emissions of nitrous oxide (N2O), a potent greenhouse gas. This study will explore how rates of various components of nitrogen cycling respond to increasing proportions of A. miquelii litter in Eucalyptus forests. By analyzing the quality and quantity of litterfall from plants, the soil microbial activity responsible for processing plant litter and its nitrogenous components, and the emissions of N2O from forest soils, the researcher will determine the increasing contribution of A. miquelii to soil processes and nitrogen cycling in previously nitrogen-poor systems.

This award, under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program, supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Australian Academy of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Holly Andrews has completed the research experience "Nitrogen cycle responses to increasing presence of parasitic mistletoes in Australian eucalypt forests" supported by the Australian subset of the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI).  During the award period, she conducted a field study at the Hawkesbury Institute for the Environment (HIE) at Western Sydney University (WSU) under the mentorship of Dr. Elise Pendall, a well-known ecosystem ecologist and soil scientist.  The objectives of this study were to characterize the impacts of mistletoes -- parasitic plants which have become increasingly prevalent in Australian forests -- on soil health and nutrient cycling in eucalyptus forests in Eastern Australia.  Mistletoes are known to induce death in parts of or in entire trees, but their nutrient-rich leaf litter may be a natural fertilizer for forest soils that are naturally nutrient-poor; Andrews and Pendall aimed to explore the consequences of increased mistletoe litterfall for nutrient cycling and forest stability in the face of other environmental stressors such as drought.

Using an experimental forest just off of HIE's campus, Andrews established study plots containing eucalyptus trees with high concentrations of mistletoe and low concentrations of mistletoe, as well as comparative study plots containing unparasitized Melaleuca tea trees, another dominant tree in Australian woodlands.  Over the course of 8 weeks, Andrews collected leaf litter and soil samples from each of these study plots and analyzed their nutrient properties.  While mistletoe litter did not differ significantly from eucalyptus litter in its carbon and nitrogen content, study plots with high parasitism did incur higher quantities of leaf litter.  Soils located under highly-parasitized eucalyptus trees also contained higher quantities of ammonium, microbial biomass, and carbon than those under sparsely-infected eucalyptus and unparasitized melaleuca trees, and generated higher emissions of carbon dioxide when soils were incubated over 24 hours in lab conditions.  In an additional experiment where leaf litter was experimentally added, removed, or left untouched, gas samples were collected and analyzed as an assessment of litter contributions to greenhouse gas emissions from melaleuca soils and from eucalyptus soils under low and high parasitism.  While field measurements of gas emissions were highly variable and no statistically significant differences were observed among litter treatments, litter supplements tended to produce higher carbon dioxide emissions from soils, and CO2 emissions from lab-incubated soils were significantly higher from parasitized soils than from unparasitized and Melaleuca soils.  Nitrous oxide emissions in the field and in the lab did not respond strongly to parasitism but did decrease throughout the study, which may be due to soil drying following a June rain event.  

In addition to collecting field data, Andrews had multiple opportunities to absorb Australian culture and to visit the Australian wildlands.  Being close to Sydney, she visited the city frequently and participated in local festivals and city-wide cultural events.  She attended a performance at the Sydney Opera House; went scuba diving off the shores of Wollongong; explored two national parks in the area; and hiked in the Blue Mountains.  Andrews also traveled to the rain forests of Tasmania and to Melbourne, where she developed a deeper understanding of the Australian culture and history that was not as visible in more cosmopolitan Sydney.

After returning to the United States, Andrews and Pendall have continued to collaborate.  They submitted a virtual poster to the 2017 American Geophysical Union (AGU) Virtual Poster Showcase which highlights the consequences of mistletoe parasitism for nutrient cycling in Australian woodlands and the potential for elevated greenhouse gas emissions from woodland soils.  While their poster did not receive an award, participating the the Virtual Poster Showcase was a unique opportunity for science communication since a video explaining this poster and its significance now exists on YouTube for the public to view.

While the project "Nitrogen cycle responses to increasing presence of parasitic mistletoes in Australian eucalypt forests" will not be part of Andrews's dissertation, the field techniques she learned and the network she built at HIE will play a significant part in her career moving forward.  Andrews plans to pursue a research career, likely in academia, and Pendall will continue to serve as a mentor and role model during and beyond graduate school.

 


Last Modified: 10/02/2018
Modified by: Holly M Andrews
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Holly Andrews has completed the research experience "Nitrogen cycle responses to increasing presence of parasitic mistletoes in Australian eucalypt forests" supported by the Australian subset of the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI). During the award period, she conducted a field study at the Hawkesbury Institute for the Environment (HIE) at Western Sydney University (WSU) under the mentorship of Dr. Elise Pendall, a well-known ecosystem ecologist and soil scientist. The objectives of this study were to characterize the impacts of mistletoes -- parasitic plants which have become increasingly prevalent in Australian forests -- on soil health and nutrient cycling in eucalyptus forests in Eastern Australia. Using an experimental forest just off of HIE's campus, Andrews established study plots containing eucalyptus trees with high concentrations of mistletoe and low concentrations of mistletoe, as well as comparative study plots containing unparasitized Melaleuca tea trees, another dominant tree in Australian woodlands. While the project "Nitrogen cycle responses to increasing presence of parasitic mistletoes in Australian eucalypt forests" will not be part of Andrews's dissertation, the field techniques she learned and the network she built at HIE will play a significant part in her career moving forward. Andrews plans to pursue a research career, likely in academia, and Pendall will continue to serve as a mentor and role model during and beyond graduate school.
